data.title: Opening act for Otis Redding
data.text:
Post by Len Blanks

Post by Dave Allen

Having lived in Madison, Wisconsin for over twenty years, I thought

I'd heard just about every story there was to hear about the 1967

crash of Otis' Twin Beech into Lake Monona. I was wrong. I just

learned a new little factoid today (it may be common knowledge to

some, but it was new to me).

Reproductions of the poster for Redding's December 10, 1967 concert

in Madison are pretty common around here, so I was already aware of

the name of the opening act. What I didn't know was that the opening

act was an early incarnation of a hit 70's band, one that I've seen

in concert several times.

What was the name of the band at the bottom of the bill that fateful

day, and what hit 70s band did they later become?

Art and the Window Washers

Len knows that this isn't the answer, but I'm tempted to give him full

credit points anyway. Len, your knowledge of obscure Madison related

trivia is commendable. I wish I still had my old "Art is a window

washer" t-shirt.

Art Nesson, commonly referred to as "Art the Window Washer," was one of

the many colorful characters who populated State Street in Madison. Art

always had a bucket, some dirty newspaper, and a squeegee on hand to

perform his trademark occupation. Art's window washing afforded him a

beverage or couple of bucks here and there from State Street vendors.

But Art's claim to fame was a t-shirt created by some University of

Wisconsin art students.

T-shirt front: "What is Art?"

T-shirt back: "Art is a window washer"

These shirts were a familiar sight on the backs of UW students from the

1960s through the 1980s.

--

Dave

Questn Authority

Todd, Wanted to look up information & found this on a site referencing

the Champaign bar:

"The Buffum Tool Company played the Champaign bar/small concert circuit,

along with other obscure parts of the Midwest, ca. 1965 to 1968.

Philip Ross, Frank Pytko, Rick Thady and Donald McCrea Kennedy, Gerry

Smith.

The band was originally called The Barbarians. Their first drummer of

note was named Snake Larsen, and when he left the band they auditioned a

few drummers, including me (Frank) and this guy named Alan Gratzer. I

got the job, based mostly on the fact that I had longer hair than Alan

did. Image was very important in 1965. Alan then hooked up with Neal

Doughty, formed REO Speedwagon, and the rest is history. Buffum Tool Co.

headed west to San Francisco during the Summer of Love and did a

three-week stint at The Matrix while camping out in the Steve Miller

Band's attic. Fame eluded us. On returning to the Midwest, Phil Ross

left the band to pursue a career in graphic arts and was replaced by

singer Brian Cook and bassist Larry Minton, formerly of Somebody Groovy

(with guitarist Garret Oostdyck, post-Finchley Boys). One of our most

memorable gigs was substituting for Otis Redding at Ken Adamany's club

in Madison, WI. Otis had just crashed into Lake Michigan, and the crowd

showed up expecting Otis, and instead got six white guys playing folk

rock. Imagine their surprise. We survived that one and went on to sub at

the same club for Moby Grape when they didn't show up for some reason.

Sorry, no refunds."
